p: Clutch size in reed warblers appears to be less variable than in many other passerine species [ 53]. This may represent the outcome of a trade-off between current reproductive effort and future reproduction and survival [ 54]. Maintaining small clutch sizes reduces the period of egg-laying, as well as the duration required for incubation and nestling periods [ 55]. The advantages of this include reducing the period of vulnerability to predators and brood parasites [ 56], as well as leading to the earlier initiation of subsequent broods. Such benefits may outweigh the gains of increasing the clutch size of the first brood.
